1.verse: After King Ahab’s death the nation of Moab declared its independence and refused to pay tribute to Israel any longer.

2.verse: Israel’s new king, Ahaziah, had fallen off the upstairs porch of his palace at Samaria and was seriously injured. He sent messengers to the temple of the god Baal-zebub at Ekron to ask whether he would recover.

3.verse: But the Angel of the Lord told Elijah the prophet, “Go and meet the messengers and ask them, ‘Is it true that there is no God in Israel? Is that why you are going to Baal-zebub, the god of Ekron, to ask whether the king will get well?

4.verse: Because King Ahaziah has done this, the Lord says that he will never leave the bed he is lying on; he will surely die.’” When Elijah told the messengers this, they returned immediately to the king. “Why have you returned so soon?” he asked them.

5.verse: Because King Ahaziah has done this, the Lord says that he will never leave the bed he is lying on; he will surely die.’” When Elijah told the messengers this, they returned immediately to the king. “Why have you returned so soon?” he asked them.

6.verse: “A man came up to us,” they said, “and told us to go back to the king and tell him, ‘The Lord wants to know why you are asking questions of Baal-zebub, the god of Ekron. Is it because there is no God in Israel? Now, since you have done this, you will not leave the bed you are lying on; you will surely die.’”

7.verse: “Who was this fellow?” the king demanded. “What did he look like?”

8.verse: “He was a hairy man,” they replied, “with a wide leather belt.” “It was Elijah the prophet!” the king exclaimed.

9.verse: Then he sent an army captain with fifty soldiers to arrest him. They found him sitting on top of a hill. The captain said to him, “O man of God, the king has commanded you to come along with us.”

10.verse: But Elijah replied, “If I am a man of God, let fire come down from heaven and destroy you and your fifty men!” Then lightning struck them and killed them all!

11.verse: So the king sent another captain with fifty men to demand, “O man of God, the king says that you must come down right away.”

12.verse: Elijah replied, “If I am a man of God, let fire come down from heaven and destroy you and your fifty men.” And again the fire from God burned them up.

13.verse: Once more the king sent fifty men, but this time the captain fell to his knees before Elijah and pleaded with him, “O man of God, please spare my life and the lives of these, your fifty servants.

14.verse: Have mercy on us! Don’t destroy us as you did the others.”

15.verse: Then the Angel of the Lord said to Elijah, “Don’t be afraid. Go with him.” So Elijah went to the king.

16.verse: “Why did you send messengers to Baal-zebub, the god of Ekron, to ask about your sickness?” Elijah demanded. “Is it because there is no God in Israel to ask? Because you have done this, you shall not leave this bed; you will surely die.”

17.verse: So Ahaziah died as the Lord had predicted through Elijah, and his brother Joram became the new king—for Ahaziah did not have a son to succeed him. This occurred in the second year of the reign of King Jehoram (son of Jehoshaphat) of Judah.

18.verse: The rest of the history of Ahaziah’s reign is recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Israel.

1.verse: Now the time came for the Lord to take Elijah to heaven—by means of a whirlwind! Elijah said to Elisha as they left Gilgal, “Stay here, for the Lord has told me to go to Bethel.” But Elisha replied, “I swear to God that I won’t leave you!” So they went on together to Bethel.

2.verse: Now the time came for the Lord to take Elijah to heaven—by means of a whirlwind! Elijah said to Elisha as they left Gilgal, “Stay here, for the Lord has told me to go to Bethel.” But Elisha replied, “I swear to God that I won’t leave you!” So they went on together to Bethel.

3.verse: There the young prophets of Bethel Seminary came out to meet them and asked Elisha, “Did you know that the Lord is going to take Elijah away from you today?” “Quiet!” Elisha snapped. “Of course I know it.”

4.verse: Then Elijah said to Elisha, “Please stay here in Bethel, for the Lord has sent me to Jericho.” But Elisha replied again, “I swear to God that I won’t leave you.” So they went on together to Jericho.

5.verse: Then the students at Jericho Seminary came to Elisha and asked him, “Do you know that the Lord is going to take away your master today?” “Will you please be quiet?” he commanded. “Of course I know it!”

6.verse: Then Elijah said to Elisha, “Please stay here, for the Lord has sent me to the Jordan River.” But Elisha replied as before, “I swear to God that I won’t leave you.” So they went on together and stood beside the Jordan River as fifty of the young prophets watched from a distance.

7.verse: Then Elijah said to Elisha, “Please stay here, for the Lord has sent me to the Jordan River.” But Elisha replied as before, “I swear to God that I won’t leave you.” So they went on together and stood beside the Jordan River as fifty of the young prophets watched from a distance.

8.verse: Then Elijah folded his cloak together and struck the water with it; and the river divided and they went across on dry ground!

9.verse: When they arrived on the other side Elijah said to Elisha, “What wish shall I grant you before I am taken away?” And Elisha replied, “Please grant me twice as much prophetic power as you have had.”

10.verse: “You have asked a hard thing,” Elijah replied. “If you see me when I am taken from you, then you will get your request. But if not, then you won’t.”

11.verse: As they were walking along, talking, suddenly a chariot of fire, drawn by horses of fire, appeared and drove between them, separating them, and Elijah was carried by a whirlwind into heaven.

12.verse: Elisha saw it and cried out, “My father! My father! The chariot of Israel and the charioteers!” As they disappeared from sight he tore his robe.

13.verse: Then he picked up Elijah’s cloak and returned to the bank of the Jordan River, and struck the water with it. “Where is the Lord God of Elijah?” he cried out. And the water parted and Elisha went across!

14.verse: Then he picked up Elijah’s cloak and returned to the bank of the Jordan River, and struck the water with it. “Where is the Lord God of Elijah?” he cried out. And the water parted and Elisha went across!

15.verse: When the young prophets of Jericho saw what had happened, they exclaimed, “The spirit of Elijah rests upon Elisha!” And they went to meet him and greeted him respectfully.

16.verse: “Sir,” they said, “just say the word and fifty of our best athletes will search the wilderness for your master; perhaps the Spirit of the Lord has left him on some mountain or in some ravine.” “No,” Elisha said, “don’t bother.”

17.verse: But they kept urging until he was embarrassed and finally said, “All right, go ahead.” Then fifty men searched for three days, but didn’t find him.

18.verse: Elisha was still at Jericho when they returned. “Didn’t I tell you not to go?” he growled.

19.verse: Now a delegation of the city officials of Jericho visited Elisha. “We have a problem,” they told him. “This city is located in beautiful natural surroundings, as you can see; but the water is bad and causes our women to have miscarriages.”

20.verse: “Well,” he said, “bring me a new bowl filled with salt.” So they brought it to him.

21.verse: Then he went out to the city well and threw the salt in and declared, “The Lord has healed these waters. They shall no longer cause death or miscarriage.”

22.verse: And sure enough! The water was purified, just as Elisha had said.

23.verse: From Jericho he went to Bethel. As he was walking along the road, a gang of young men from the city began mocking and making fun of him because of his bald head.

24.verse: He turned around and cursed them in the name of the Lord; and two female bears came out of the woods and tore forty-two of them.

25.verse: Then he went to Mount Carmel and finally returned to Samaria.

1.verse: Ahab’s son Joram began his reign over Israel during the eighteenth year of the reign of King Jehoshaphat of Judah; and he reigned twelve years. His capital was Samaria.

2.verse: He was a very evil man, but not as wicked as his father and mother had been, for he at least tore down the pillar to Baal that his father had made.

3.verse: Nevertheless he still clung to the great sin of Jeroboam (the son of Nebat), who had led the people of Israel into the worship of idols.

4.verse: King Mesha of Moab and his people were sheep ranchers. They paid Israel an annual tribute of 100,000 lambs and the wool of 100,000 rams;

5.verse: but after Ahab’s death, the king of Moab rebelled against Israel.

6.verse: So King Joram mustered the Israeli army and sent this message to King Jehoshaphat of Judah: “The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you help me fight him?” “Of course I will,” Jehoshaphat replied. “My people and horses are yours to command. What are your battle plans?” “We’ll attack from the wilderness of Edom,” Joram replied.

7.verse: So King Joram mustered the Israeli army and sent this message to King Jehoshaphat of Judah: “The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you help me fight him?” “Of course I will,” Jehoshaphat replied. “My people and horses are yours to command. What are your battle plans?” “We’ll attack from the wilderness of Edom,” Joram replied.

8.verse: So King Joram mustered the Israeli army and sent this message to King Jehoshaphat of Judah: “The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you help me fight him?” “Of course I will,” Jehoshaphat replied. “My people and horses are yours to command. What are your battle plans?” “We’ll attack from the wilderness of Edom,” Joram replied.

9.verse: So their two armies, now joined also by troops from Edom, moved along a roundabout route through the wilderness for seven days; but there was no water for the men or their pack animals.

10.verse: “Oh, what shall we do?” the king of Israel cried out. “The Lord has brought us here to let the king of Moab defeat us.”

11.verse: But Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, asked, “Isn’t there a prophet of the Lord with us? If so, we can find out what to do!” “Elisha is here,” one of the king of Israel’s officers replied. Then he added, “He was Elijah’s assistant.”

12.verse: “Fine,” Jehoshaphat said. “He’s just the man we want.” So the kings of Israel, Judah, and Edom went to consult Elisha.

13.verse: “I want no part of you,” Elisha snarled at King Joram of Israel. “Go to the false prophets of your father and mother!” But King Joram replied, “No! For it is the Lord who has called us here to be destroyed by the king of Moab!”

14.verse: “I swear by the Lord God that I wouldn’t bother with you except for the presence of King Jehoshaphat of Judah,” Elisha replied.

15.verse: “Now bring me someone to play the lute.” And as the lute was played, the message of the Lord came to Elisha:

16.verse: “The Lord says to fill this dry valley with trenches to hold the water he will send.

17.verse: You won’t see wind nor rain, but this valley will be filled with water, and you will have plenty for yourselves and for your animals!

18.verse: But this is only the beginning, for the Lord will make you victorious over the army of Moab!

19.verse: You will conquer the best of their cities—even those that are fortified—and ruin all the good land with stones.”

20.verse: And sure enough, the next day at about the time when the morning sacrifice was offered—look! Water! It was flowing from the direction of Edom, and soon there was water everywhere.

21.verse: Meanwhile, when the people of Moab heard about the three armies marching against them, they mobilized every man who could fight, old and young, and stationed themselves along their frontier.

22.verse: But early the next morning the sun looked red as it shone across the water!

23.verse: “Blood!” they exclaimed. “The three armies have attacked and killed each other! Let’s go and collect the loot!”

24.verse: But when they arrived at the Israeli camp, the army of Israel rushed out and began killing them; and the army of Moab fled. Then the men of Israel moved forward into the land of Moab, destroying everything as they went.

25.verse: They destroyed the cities, threw stones on every good piece of land, stopped up the wells, and felled the fruit trees; finally, only Fort Kir-hareseth was left, but even that finally fell to them.

26.verse: When the king of Moab saw that the battle had been lost, he led 700 of his swordsmen in a last desperate attempt to break through to the king of Edom; but he failed.

27.verse: Then he took his oldest son, who was to have been the next king, and to the horror of the Israeli army, killed him and sacrificed him as a burnt offering upon the wall. So the army of Israel turned back in disgust to their own land.

1.verse: One day the wife of one of the seminary students came to Elisha to tell him of her husband’s death. He was a man who had loved God, she said. But he had owed some money when he died, and now the creditor was demanding it back. If she didn’t pay, he said he would take her two sons as his slaves.

2.verse: “What shall I do?” Elisha asked. “How much food do you have in the house?” “Nothing at all, except a jar of olive oil,” she replied.

3.verse: “Then borrow many pots and pans from your friends and neighbors!” he instructed.

4.verse: “Go into your house with your sons and shut the door behind you. Then pour olive oil from your jar into the pots and pans, setting them aside as they are filled!”

5.verse: So she did. Her sons brought the pots and pans to her, and she filled one after another!

6.verse: Soon every container was full to the brim! “Bring me another jar,” she said to her sons. “There aren’t any more!” they told her. And then the oil stopped flowing!

7.verse: When she told the prophet what had happened, he said to her, “Go and sell the oil and pay your debt, and there will be enough money left for you and your sons to live on!”

8.verse: One day Elisha went to Shunem. A prominent woman of the city invited him in to eat, and afterwards, whenever he passed that way, he stopped for dinner.

9.verse: She said to her husband, “I’m sure this man who stops in from time to time is a holy prophet.

10.verse: Let’s make a little room for him on the roof; we can put in a bed, a table, a chair, and a lamp, and he will have a place to stay whenever he comes by.”

11.verse: Once when he was resting in the room he said to his servant Gehazi, “Tell the woman I want to speak to her.” When she came,

12.verse: Once when he was resting in the room he said to his servant Gehazi, “Tell the woman I want to speak to her.” When she came,

13.verse: he said to Gehazi, “Tell her that we appreciate her kindness to us. Now ask her what we can do for her. Does she want me to put in a good word for her to the king or to the general of the army?” “No,” she replied, “I am perfectly content.”

14.verse: “What can we do for her?” he asked Gehazi afterwards. He suggested, “She doesn’t have a son, and her husband is an old man.”

15.verse: “Call her back again,” Elisha told him. When she returned, he talked to her as she stood in the doorway. “Next year at about this time you shall have a son!” “O man of God,” she exclaimed, “don’t lie to me like that!”

16.verse: “Call her back again,” Elisha told him. When she returned, he talked to her as she stood in the doorway. “Next year at about this time you shall have a son!” “O man of God,” she exclaimed, “don’t lie to me like that!”

17.verse: But it was true; the woman soon conceived and had a baby boy the following year, just as Elisha had predicted.

18.verse: One day when her child was older, he went out to visit his father, who was working with the reapers.

19.verse: He complained about a headache and soon was moaning in pain. His father said to one of the servants, “Carry him home to his mother.”

20.verse: So he took him home, and his mother held him on her lap; but around noontime he died.

21.verse: She carried him up to the bed of the prophet and shut the door;

22.verse: then she sent a message to her husband: “Send one of the servants and a donkey so that I can hurry to the prophet and come right back.”

23.verse: “Why today?” he asked. “This isn’t a religious holiday.” But she said, “It’s important. I must go.”

24.verse: So she saddled the donkey and said to the servant, “Hurry! Don’t slow down for my comfort unless I tell you to.”

25.verse: As she approached Mount Carmel, Elisha saw her in the distance and said to Gehazi, “Look, that woman from Shunem is coming.

26.verse: Run and meet her and ask her what the trouble is. See if her husband is all right and if the child is well.” “Yes,” she told Gehazi, “everything is fine.”

27.verse: But when she came to Elisha at the mountain she fell to the ground before him and caught hold of his feet. Gehazi began to push her away, but the prophet said, “Leave her alone; something is deeply troubling her and the Lord hasn’t told me what it is.”

28.verse: Then she said, “It was you who said I’d have a son. And I begged you not to lie to me!”

29.verse: Then he said to Gehazi, “Quick, take my staff! Don’t talk to anyone along the way. Hurry! Lay the staff upon the child’s face.”

30.verse: But the boy’s mother said, “I swear to God that I won’t go home without you.” So Elisha returned with her.

31.verse: Gehazi went on ahead and laid the staff upon the child’s face, but nothing happened. There was no sign of life. He returned to meet Elisha and told him, “The child is still dead.”

32.verse: When Elisha arrived, the child was indeed dead, lying there upon the prophet’s bed.

33.verse: He went in and shut the door behind him and prayed to the Lord.

34.verse: Then he lay upon the child’s body, placing his mouth upon the child’s mouth, and his eyes upon the child’s eyes, and his hands upon the child’s hands. And the child’s body began to grow warm again!

35.verse: Then the prophet went down and walked back and forth in the house a few times; returning upstairs, he stretched himself again upon the child. This time the little boy sneezed seven times and opened his eyes!

36.verse: Then the prophet summoned Gehazi. “Call her!” he said. And when she came in, he said, “Here’s your son!”

37.verse: She fell to the floor at his feet and then picked up her son and went out.

38.verse: Elisha now returned to Gilgal, but there was a famine in the land. One day as he was teaching the young prophets, he said to Gehazi, “Make some stew for supper for these men.”

39.verse: One of the young men went out into the field to gather vegetables and came back with some wild gourds. He shredded them and put them into a kettle without realizing that they were poisonous.

40.verse: But after the men had eaten a bite or two they cried out, “Oh, sir, there’s poison in this stew!”

41.verse: “Bring me some meal,” Elisha said. He threw it into the kettle and said, “Now it’s all right! Go ahead and eat!” And then it didn’t harm them.

42.verse: One day a man from Baal-shalishah brought Elisha a sack of fresh corn and twenty individual loaves of barley bread made from the first grain of his harvest. Elisha told Gehazi to use it to feed the young prophets.

43.verse: “What?” Gehazi exclaimed. “Feed one hundred men with only this?” But Elisha said, “Go ahead, for the Lord says there will be plenty for all, and some will even be left over!”

44.verse: And sure enough, there was, just as the Lord had said!

1.verse: The king of Syria had high admiration for Naaman, the commander-in-chief of his army, for he had led his troops to many glorious victories. So he was a great hero, but he was a leper.

2.verse: Bands of Syrians had invaded the land of Israel, and among their captives was a little girl who had been given to Naaman’s wife as a maid.

3.verse: One day the little girl said to her mistress, “I wish my master would go to see the prophet in Samaria. He would heal him of his leprosy!”

4.verse: Naaman told the king what the little girl had said.

5.verse: “Go and visit the prophet,” the king told him. “I will send a letter of introduction for you to carry to the king of Israel.” So Naaman started out, taking gifts of $20,000 in silver, $60,000 in gold, and ten suits of clothing.

6.verse: The letter to the king of Israel said: “The man bringing this letter is my servant Naaman; I want you to heal him of his leprosy.”

7.verse: When the king of Israel read it, he tore his clothes and said, “This man sends me a leper to heal! Am I God, that I can kill and give life? He is only trying to get an excuse to invade us again.”

8.verse: But when Elisha the prophet heard about the king of Israel’s plight, he sent this message to him: “Why are you so upset? Send Naaman to me, and he will learn that there is a true prophet of God here in Israel.”

9.verse: So Naaman arrived with his horses and chariots and stood at the door of Elisha’s home.

10.verse: Elisha sent a messenger out to tell him to go and wash in the Jordan River seven times and he would be healed of every trace of his leprosy!

11.verse: But Naaman was angry and stalked away. “Look,” he said, “I thought at least he would come out and talk to me! I expected him to wave his hand over the leprosy and call upon the name of the Lord his God and heal me!

12.verse: Aren’t the Abana River and Pharpar River of Damascus better than all the rivers of Israel put together? If it’s rivers I need, I’ll wash at home and get rid of my leprosy.” So he went away in a rage.

13.verse: But his officers tried to reason with him and said, “If the prophet had told you to do some great thing, wouldn’t you have done it? So you should certainly obey him when he says simply to go and wash and be cured!”

14.verse: So Naaman went down to the Jordan River and dipped himself seven times, as the prophet had told him to. And his flesh became as healthy as a little child’s, and he was healed!

15.verse: Then he and his entire party went back to find the prophet; they stood humbly before him and Naaman said, “I know at last that there is no God in all the world except in Israel; now please accept my gifts.”

16.verse: But Elisha replied, “I swear by Jehovah my God that I will not accept them.” Naaman urged him to take them, but he absolutely refused.

17.verse: “Well,” Naaman said, “all right. But please give me two muleloads of earth to take back with me, for from now on I will never again offer any burnt offerings or sacrifices to any other god except the Lord.

18.verse: However, may the Lord pardon me this one thing—when my master the king goes into the temple of the god Rimmon to worship there and leans on my arm, may the Lord pardon me when I bow too.”

19.verse: “All right,” Elisha said. So Naaman started home again.

20.verse: But Gehazi, Elisha’s servant, said to himself, “My master shouldn’t have let this fellow get away without taking his gifts. I will chase after him and get something from him.”

21.verse: So Gehazi caught up with him. When Naaman saw him coming, he jumped down from his chariot and ran to meet him. “Is everything all right?” he asked.

22.verse: “Yes,” he said, “but my master has sent me to tell you that two young prophets from the hills of Ephraim have just arrived, and he would like $2,000 in silver and two suits to give to them.”

23.verse: “Take $4,000,” Naaman insisted. He gave him two expensive robes, tied up the money in two bags, and gave them to two of his servants to carry back with Gehazi.

24.verse: But when they arrived at the hill where Elisha lived, Gehazi took the bags from the servants and sent the men back. Then he hid the money in his house.

25.verse: When he went in to his master, Elisha asked him, “Where have you been, Gehazi?” “I haven’t been anywhere,” he replied.

26.verse: But Elisha asked him, “Don’t you realize that I was there in thought when Naaman stepped down from his chariot to meet you? Is this the time to receive money and clothing and olive farms and vineyards and sheep and oxen and servants?

27.verse: Because you have done this, Naaman’s leprosy shall be upon you and upon your children and your children’s children forever.” And Gehazi walked from the room a leper, his skin as white as snow.

1.verse: One day the seminary students came to Elisha and told him, “As you can see, our dormitory is too small. Tell us, as our president, whether we can build a new one down beside the Jordan River, where there are plenty of logs.” “All right,” he told them, “go ahead.”

2.verse: One day the seminary students came to Elisha and told him, “As you can see, our dormitory is too small. Tell us, as our president, whether we can build a new one down beside the Jordan River, where there are plenty of logs.” “All right,” he told them, “go ahead.”

3.verse: “Please, sir, come with us,” someone suggested. “I will,” he said.

4.verse: When they arrived at the Jordan, they began cutting down trees;

5.verse: but as one of them was chopping, his axhead fell into the river. “Oh, sir,” he cried, “it was borrowed!”

6.verse: “Where did it fall?” the prophet asked. The youth showed him the place, and Elisha cut a stick and threw it into the water; and the axhead rose to the surface and floated!

7.verse: “Grab it,” Elisha said to him; and he did.

8.verse: Once when the king of Syria was at war with Israel, he said to his officers, “We will mobilize our forces at ____” (naming the place).

9.verse: Immediately Elisha warned the king of Israel, “Don’t go near ____” (naming the same place) “for the Syrians are planning to mobilize their troops there!”

10.verse: The king sent a scout to see if Elisha was right, and sure enough, he had saved him from disaster. This happened several times.

11.verse: The king of Syria was puzzled. He called together his officers and demanded, “Which of you is the traitor? Who has been informing the king of Israel about my plans?”

12.verse: “It’s not us, sir,” one of the officers replied. “Elisha, the prophet, tells the king of Israel even the words you speak in the privacy of your bedroom!”

13.verse: “Go and find out where he is, and we’ll send troops to seize him,” the king exclaimed. And the report came back, “Elisha is at Dothan.”

14.verse: So one night the king of Syria sent a great army with many chariots and horses to surround the city.

15.verse: When the prophet’s servant got up early the next morning and went outside, there were troops, horses, and chariots everywhere. “Alas, my master, what shall we do now?” he cried out to Elisha.

16.verse: “Don’t be afraid!” Elisha told him. “For our army is bigger than theirs!”

17.verse: Then Elisha prayed, “Lord, open his eyes and let him see!” And the Lord opened the young man’s eyes so that he could see horses of fire and chariots of fire everywhere upon the mountain!

18.verse: As the Syrian army advanced upon them, Elisha prayed, “Lord, please make them blind.” And he did.

19.verse: Then Elisha went out and told them, “You’ve come the wrong way! This isn’t the right city! Follow me and I will take you to the man you’re looking for.” And he led them to Samaria!

20.verse: As soon as they arrived Elisha prayed, “Lord, now open their eyes and let them see.” And the Lord did, and they discovered that they were in Samaria, the capital city of Israel!

21.verse: When the king of Israel saw them, he shouted to Elisha, “Oh, sir, shall I kill them? Shall I kill them?”

22.verse: “Of course not!” Elisha told him. “Do we kill prisoners of war? Give them food and drink and send them home again.”

23.verse: So the king made a great feast for them and then sent them home to their king. And after that the Syrian raiders stayed away from the land of Israel.

24.verse: Later on, however, King Ben-hadad of Syria mustered his entire army and besieged Samaria.

25.verse: As a result there was a great famine in the city, and after a long while even a donkey’s head sold for fifty dollars and a pint of dove’s dung brought three dollars!

26.verse: One day as the king of Israel was walking along the wall of the city, a woman called to him, “Help, my lord the king!” “If the Lord doesn’t help you, what can I do?” he retorted. “I have neither food nor wine to give you. However, what’s the matter?” She replied, “This woman proposed that we eat my son one day and her son the next. So we boiled my son and ate him, but the next day when I said, ‘Kill your son so we can eat him,’ she hid him.” When the king heard this he tore his clothes. (The people watching noticed through the rip he tore in them that he was wearing an inner robe made of sackcloth next to his flesh.)

29.verse: One day as the king of Israel was walking along the wall of the city, a woman called to him, “Help, my lord the king!” “If the Lord doesn’t help you, what can I do?” he retorted. “I have neither food nor wine to give you. However, what’s the matter?” She replied, “This woman proposed that we eat my son one day and her son the next. So we boiled my son and ate him, but the next day when I said, ‘Kill your son so we can eat him,’ she hid him.” When the king heard this he tore his clothes. (The people watching noticed through the rip he tore in them that he was wearing an inner robe made of sackcloth next to his flesh.)

30.verse: One day as the king of Israel was walking along the wall of the city, a woman called to him, “Help, my lord the king!” “If the Lord doesn’t help you, what can I do?” he retorted. “I have neither food nor wine to give you. However, what’s the matter?” She replied, “This woman proposed that we eat my son one day and her son the next. So we boiled my son and ate him, but the next day when I said, ‘Kill your son so we can eat him,’ she hid him.” When the king heard this he tore his clothes. (The people watching noticed through the rip he tore in them that he was wearing an inner robe made of sackcloth next to his flesh.)

31.verse: “May God kill me if I don’t execute Elisha this very day,” the king vowed.

32.verse: Elisha was sitting in his house at a meeting with the elders of Israel when the king sent a messenger to summon him. But before the messenger arrived Elisha said to the elders, “This murderer has sent a man to kill me. When he arrives, shut the door and keep him out, for his master will soon follow him.”

33.verse: While Elisha was still saying this, the messenger arrived followed by the king. “The Lord has caused this mess,” the king stormed. “Why should I expect any help from him?”

1.verse: Elisha replied, “The Lord says that by this time tomorrow two gallons of flour or four gallons of barley grain will be sold in the markets of Samaria for a dollar!”

2.verse: The officer assisting the king said, “That couldn’t happen if the Lord made windows in the sky!” But Elisha replied, “You will see it happen, but you won’t be able to buy any of it!”

3.verse: Now there were four lepers sitting outside the city gates. “Why sit here until we die?” they asked each other.

4.verse: “We will starve if we stay here and we will starve if we go back into the city; so we might as well go out and surrender to the Syrian army. If they let us live, so much the better; but if they kill us, we would have died anyway.”

5.verse: So that evening they went out to the camp of the Syrians, but there was no one there!

6.verse: (For the Lord had made the whole Syrian army hear the clatter of speeding chariots and a loud galloping of horses and the sounds of a great army approaching. “The king of Israel has hired the Hittites and Egyptians to attack us,” they cried out.

7.verse: So they panicked and fled into the night, abandoning their tents, horses, donkeys, and everything else.)

8.verse: When the lepers arrived at the edge of the camp they went into one tent after another, eating, drinking wine, and carrying out silver and gold and clothing and hiding it.

9.verse: Finally they said to each other, “This isn’t right. This is wonderful news, and we aren’t sharing it with anyone! Even if we wait until morning, some terrible calamity will certainly fall upon us; come on, let’s go back and tell the people at the palace.”

10.verse: So they went back to the city and told the watchmen what had happened—they had gone out to the Syrian camp and no one was there! The horses and donkeys were tethered and the tents were all in order, but there was not a soul around.

11.verse: Then the watchmen shouted the news to those in the palace.

12.verse: The king got out of bed and told his officers, “I know what has happened. The Syrians know we are starving, so they have left their camp and have hidden in the fields, thinking that we will be lured out of the city. Then they will attack us and make slaves of us and get in.”

13.verse: One of his officers replied, “We’d better send out scouts to see. Let them take five of the remaining horses—if something happens to the animals it won’t be any greater loss than if they stay here and die with the rest of us!”

14.verse: Four chariot horses were found and the king sent out two charioteers to see where the Syrians had gone.

15.verse: They followed a trail of clothing and equipment all the way to the Jordan River—thrown away by the Syrians in their haste. The scouts returned and told the king,

16.verse: and the people of Samaria rushed out and plundered the camp of the Syrians. So it was true that two gallons of flour and four gallons of barley were sold that day for one dollar, just as the Lord had said!

17.verse: The king appointed his special assistant to control the traffic at the gate, but he was knocked down and trampled and killed as the people rushed out. This is what Elisha had predicted on the previous day when the king had come to arrest him,

18.verse: and the prophet had told the king that flour and barley would sell for so little on the following day.

19.verse: The king’s officer had replied, “That couldn’t happen even if the Lord opened the windows of heaven!” And the prophet had said, “You will see it happen, but you won’t be able to buy any of it!”

20.verse: And he couldn’t, for the people trampled him to death at the gate!

1.verse: Elisha had told the woman whose son he had brought back to life, “Take your family and move to some other country, for the Lord has called down a famine on Israel that will last for seven years.”

2.verse: So the woman took her family and lived in the land of the Philistines for seven years.

3.verse: After the famine ended, she returned to the land of Israel and went to see the king about getting back her house and land.

4.verse: Just as she came in, the king was talking with Gehazi, Elisha’s servant, and saying, “Tell me some stories of the great things Elisha has done.”

5.verse: And Gehazi was telling the king about the time when Elisha brought a little boy back to life. At that very moment, the mother of the boy walked in! “Oh, sir!” Gehazi exclaimed. “Here is the woman now, and this is her son—the very one Elisha brought back to life!”

6.verse: “Is this true?” the king asked her. And she told him that it was. So he directed one of his officials to see to it that everything she had owned was restored to her, plus the value of any crops that had been harvested during her absence.

7.verse: Afterwards Elisha went to Damascus (the capital of Syria), where King Ben-hadad lay sick. Someone told the king that the prophet had come.

8.verse: When the king heard the news, he said to Hazael, “Take a present to the man of God and tell him to ask the Lord whether I will get well again.” So Hazael took forty camel-loads of the best produce of the land as presents for Elisha and said to him, “Your son Ben-hadad, the king of Syria, has sent me to ask you whether he will recover.”

9.verse: When the king heard the news, he said to Hazael, “Take a present to the man of God and tell him to ask the Lord whether I will get well again.” So Hazael took forty camel-loads of the best produce of the land as presents for Elisha and said to him, “Your son Ben-hadad, the king of Syria, has sent me to ask you whether he will recover.”

10.verse: And Elisha replied, “Tell him, ‘Yes.’ But the Lord has shown me that he will surely die!”

11.verse: Elisha stared at Hazael until he became embarrassed, and then Elisha started crying.

12.verse: “What’s the matter, sir?” Hazael asked him. Elisha replied, “I know the terrible things you will do to the people of Israel: you will burn their forts, kill the young men, dash their babies against the rocks, and rip open the bellies of the pregnant women!”

13.verse: “Am I a dog?” Hazael asked him. “I would never do that sort of thing.” But Elisha replied, “The Lord has shown me that you are going to be the king of Syria.”

14.verse: When Hazael went back, the king asked him, “What did he tell you?” And Hazael replied, “He told me that you would recover.”

15.verse: But the next day Hazael took a blanket and dipped it in water and held it over the king’s face until he smothered to death. And Hazael became king instead.

16.verse: King Jehoram, the son of King Jehoshaphat of Judah, began his reign during the fifth year of the reign of King Joram of Israel, the son of Ahab.

17.verse: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for eight years.

18.verse: But he was as wicked as Ahab and the other kings of Israel; he even married one of Ahab’s daughters.

19.verse: Nevertheless, because God had promised his servant David that he would watch over and guide his descendants, he did not destroy Judah.

20.verse: During Jehoram’s reign, the people in Edom revolted from Judah and appointed their own king.

21.verse: King Jehoram tried unsuccessfully to crush the rebellion: he crossed the Jordan River and attacked the city of Zair, but was quickly surrounded by the army of Edom. Under cover of night he broke through their ranks, but his army deserted him and fled.

22.verse: So Edom has maintained its independence to this day. Libnah also rebelled at that time.

23.verse: The rest of the history of King Jehoram is written in The Annals of the Kings of Judah.

24.verse: He died and was buried in the royal cemetery in the City of David—the old section of Jerusalem. Then his son Ahaziah became the new king during the twelfth year of the reign of King Joram of Israel, the son of Ahab.

25.verse: He died and was buried in the royal cemetery in the City of David—the old section of Jerusalem. Then his son Ahaziah became the new king during the twelfth year of the reign of King Joram of Israel, the son of Ahab.

26.verse: Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he began to reign, but he reigned only one year in Jerusalem. His mother was Athaliah, the granddaughter of King Omri of Israel.

27.verse: He was an evil king, just as all of King Ahab’s descendants were—for he was related to Ahab by marriage.

28.verse: He joined King Joram of Israel (son of Ahab) in his war against Hazael, the king of Syria, at Ramoth-gilead. King Joram was wounded in the battle,

29.verse: so he went to Jezreel to rest and recover from his wounds. While he was there, King Ahaziah of Judah (son of Jehoram) came to visit him.

1.verse: Meanwhile Elisha had summoned one of the young prophets. “Get ready to go to Ramoth-gilead,” he told him. “Take this vial of oil with you

2.verse: and find Jehu (the son of Jehoshaphat, the son of Nimshi). Call him into a private room away from his friends,

3.verse: and pour the oil over his head. Tell him that the Lord has anointed him to be the king of Israel; then run for your life!”

4.verse: So the young prophet did as he was told. When he arrived in Ramoth-gilead,

5.verse: he found Jehu sitting around with the other army officers. “I have a message for you, sir,” he said. “For which one of us?” Jehu asked. “For you,” he replied.

6.verse: So Jehu left the others and went into the house, and the young man poured the oil over his head and said, “The Lord God of Israel says, ‘I anoint you king of the Lord’s people, Israel.

7.verse: You are to destroy the family of Ahab; you will avenge the murder of my prophets and of all my other people who were killed by Jezebel.

8.verse: The entire family of Ahab must be wiped out—every male, no matter who.

9.verse: I will destroy the family of Ahab as I destroyed the families of Jeroboam (son of Nebat) and of Baasha (son of Ahijah).

10.verse: Dogs shall eat Ahab’s wife Jezebel at Jezreel, and no one will bury her.’” Then he opened the door and ran.

11.verse: Jehu went back to his friends and one of them asked him, “What did that crazy fellow want? Is everything all right?” “You know very well who he was and what he wanted,” Jehu replied.

12.verse: “No, we don’t,” they said. “Tell us.” So he told them what the man had said and that he had been anointed king of Israel!

13.verse: They quickly carpeted the bare steps with their coats and blew a trumpet, shouting, “Jehu is king!”

14.verse: That is how Jehu (son of Jehoshaphat, son of Nimshi) rebelled against King Joram. (King Joram had been with the army at Ramoth-gilead, defending Israel against the forces of King Hazael of Syria.

15.verse: But he had returned to Jezreel to recover from his wounds.) “Since you want me to be king,” Jehu told the men who were with him, “don’t let anyone escape to Jezreel to report what we have done.”

16.verse: Then Jehu jumped into a chariot and rode to Jezreel himself to find King Joram, who was lying there wounded. (King Ahaziah of Judah was there too, for he had gone to visit him.)

17.verse: The watchman on the Tower of Jezreel saw Jehu and his company approaching and shouted, “Someone is coming.” “Send out a rider and find out if he is friend or foe,” King Joram shouted back.

18.verse: So a soldier rode out to meet Jehu. “The king wants to know whether you are friend or foe,” he demanded. “Do you come in peace?” Jehu replied, “What do you know about peace? Get behind me!” The watchman called out to the king that the messenger had met them but was not returning.

19.verse: So the king sent out a second rider. He rode up to them and demanded in the name of the king to know whether their intentions were friendly or not. Jehu answered, “What do you know about friendliness? Get behind me!”

20.verse: “He isn’t returning either!” the watchman exclaimed. “It must be Jehu, for he is driving so furiously.”

21.verse: “Quick! Get my chariot ready!” King Joram commanded. Then he and King Ahaziah of Judah rode out to meet Jehu. They met him at the field of Naboth,

22.verse: and King Joram demanded, “Do you come as a friend, Jehu?” Jehu replied, “How can there be friendship as long as the evils of your mother Jezebel are all around us?”

23.verse: Then King Joram reined the chariot horses around and fled, shouting to King Ahaziah, “There is treachery, Ahaziah! Treason!”

24.verse: Then Jehu drew his bow with his full strength and shot Joram between the shoulders; and the arrow pierced his heart, and he sank down dead in his chariot.

25.verse: Jehu said to Bidkar, his assistant, “Throw him into the field of Naboth, for once when you and I were riding along behind his father Ahab, the Lord revealed this prophecy to me:

26.verse: ‘I will repay him here on Naboth’s property for the murder of Naboth and his sons.’ So throw him out on Naboth’s field, just as the Lord said.”

27.verse: Meanwhile, King Ahaziah of Judah had fled along the road to Beth-haggan. Jehu rode after him, shouting, “Shoot him too.” So they shot him in his chariot at the place where the road climbs to Gur, near Ibleam. He was able to go on as far as Megiddo, but died there.

28.verse: His officials took him by chariot to Jerusalem where they buried him in the royal cemetery.

29.verse: (Ahaziah’s reign over Judah had begun in the twelfth year of the reign of King Joram of Israel.)

30.verse: When Jezebel heard that Jehu had come to Jezreel, she painted her eyelids and fixed her hair and sat at a window.

31.verse: When Jehu entered the gate of the palace, she shouted at him, “How are you today, you murderer! You son of a Zimri who murdered his master!”

32.verse: He looked up and saw her at the window and shouted, “Who is on my side?” And two or three eunuchs looked out at him.

33.verse: “Throw her down!” he yelled. So they threw her out the window, and her blood spattered against the wall and on the horses; and she was trampled by the horses’ hoofs.

34.verse: Then Jehu went into the palace for lunch. Afterwards he said, “Someone go and bury this cursed woman, for she is the daughter of a king.”

35.verse: But when they went out to bury her, they found only her skull, her feet, and her hands.

36.verse: When they returned and told him, he remarked, “That is just what the Lord said would happen. He told Elijah the prophet that dogs would eat her flesh

37.verse: and that her body would be scattered like manure upon the field, so that no one could tell whose it was.”

1.verse: Then Jehu wrote a letter to the city council of Samaria and to the guardians of Ahab’s seventy sons—all of whom were living there.

2.verse: “Upon receipt of this letter, select the best one of Ahab’s sons to be your king, and prepare to fight for his throne. For you have chariots and horses and a fortified city and an armory.”

3.verse: “Upon receipt of this letter, select the best one of Ahab’s sons to be your king, and prepare to fight for his throne. For you have chariots and horses and a fortified city and an armory.”

4.verse: But they were too frightened to do it. “Two kings couldn’t stand against this man! What can we do?” they said.

5.verse: So the manager of palace affairs and the city manager, together with the city council and the guardians of Ahab’s sons, sent him this message: “Jehu, we are your servants and will do anything you tell us to. We have decided that you should be our king instead of one of Ahab’s sons.”

6.verse: Jehu responded with this message: “If you are on my side and are going to obey me, bring the heads of your master’s sons to me at Jezreel at about this time tomorrow.” (These seventy sons of King Ahab were living in the homes of the chief men of the city, where they had been raised since childhood.)

7.verse: When the letter arrived, all seventy of them were murdered, and their heads were packed into baskets and presented to Jehu at Jezreel.

8.verse: When a messenger told Jehu that the heads of the king’s sons had arrived, he said to pile them in two heaps at the entrance of the city gate, and to leave them there until the next morning.

9.verse: In the morning he went out and spoke to the crowd that had gathered around them. “You aren’t to blame,” he told them. “I conspired against my master and killed him, but I didn’t kill his sons! The Lord has done that, for everything he says comes true. He declared through his servant Elijah that this would happen to Ahab’s descendants.”

10.verse: In the morning he went out and spoke to the crowd that had gathered around them. “You aren’t to blame,” he told them. “I conspired against my master and killed him, but I didn’t kill his sons! The Lord has done that, for everything he says comes true. He declared through his servant Elijah that this would happen to Ahab’s descendants.”

11.verse: Jehu then killed all the rest of the members of the family of Ahab who were in Jezreel, as well as all of his important officials, personal friends, and private chaplains. Finally, no one was left who had been close to him in any way.

12.verse: Then he set out for Samaria and stayed overnight at a shepherd’s inn along the way.

13.verse: While he was there he met the brothers of King Ahaziah of Judah. “Who are you?” he asked them. And they replied, “We are brothers of King Ahaziah. We are going to Samaria to visit the sons of King Ahab and of the Queen Mother, Jezebel.”

14.verse: “Grab them!” Jehu shouted to his men. And he took them out to the cistern and killed all forty-two of them.

15.verse: As he left the inn, he met Jehonadab, the son of Rechab, who was coming to meet him. After they had greeted each other, Jehu said to him, “Are you as loyal to me as I am to you?” “Yes,” Jehonadab replied. “Then give me your hand,” Jehu said, and he helped him into the royal chariot.

16.verse: “Now come along with me,” Jehu said, “and see how much I have done for the Lord.” So Jehonadab rode along with him.

17.verse: When he arrived in Samaria he butchered all of Ahab’s friends and relatives, just as Elijah, speaking for the Lord, had predicted. Then Jehu called a meeting of all the people of the city and said to them, “Ahab hardly worshiped Baal at all in comparison to the way I am going to!

18.verse: Summon all the prophets and priests of Baal, and call together all his worshipers. See to it that every one of them comes, for we worshipers of Baal are going to have a great celebration to praise him. Any of Baal’s worshipers who don’t come will be put to death.” But Jehu’s plan was to exterminate them.

19.verse: Summon all the prophets and priests of Baal, and call together all his worshipers. See to it that every one of them comes, for we worshipers of Baal are going to have a great celebration to praise him. Any of Baal’s worshipers who don’t come will be put to death.” But Jehu’s plan was to exterminate them.

20.verse: He sent messengers throughout all Israel summoning those who worshiped Baal; and they all came and filled the temple of Baal from one end to the other.

21.verse: He sent messengers throughout all Israel summoning those who worshiped Baal; and they all came and filled the temple of Baal from one end to the other.

22.verse: He instructed the head of the robing room, “Be sure that every worshiper wears one of the special robes.”

23.verse: Then Jehu and Jehonadab (son of Rechab) went into the temple to address the people: “Check to be sure that only those who worship Baal are here; don’t let anyone in who worships the Lord!”

24.verse: As the priests of Baal began offering sacrifices and burnt offerings, Jehu surrounded the building with eighty of his men and told them, “If you let anyone escape, you’ll pay for it with your own life.”

25.verse: As soon as he had finished sacrificing the burnt offering, Jehu went out and told his officers and men, “Go in and kill the whole bunch of them. Don’t let a single one escape.” So they slaughtered them all and dragged their bodies outside. Then Jehu’s men went into the inner temple,

26.verse: dragged out the pillar used for the worship of Baal, and burned it.

27.verse: They wrecked the temple and converted it into a public toilet, which it still is today.

28.verse: Thus Jehu destroyed every trace of Baal from Israel.

29.verse: However, he didn’t destroy the gold calves at Bethel and Dan—this was the great sin of Jeroboam (son of Nebat), for it resulted in all Israel sinning.

30.verse: Afterwards the Lord said to Jehu, “You have done well in following my instructions to destroy the dynasty of Ahab. Because of this I will cause your son, your grandson, and your great-grandson to be the kings of Israel.”

31.verse: But Jehu didn’t follow the Lord God of Israel with all his heart, for he continued to worship Jeroboam’s gold calves that had been the cause of such great sin in Israel.

32.verse: At about that time the Lord began to whittle down the size of Israel. King Hazael conquered several sections of the country east of the Jordan River, as well as all of Gilead, Gad, and Reuben; he also conquered parts of Manasseh from the Aroer River in the valley of the Arnon as far as Gilead and Bashan.

33.verse: At about that time the Lord began to whittle down the size of Israel. King Hazael conquered several sections of the country east of the Jordan River, as well as all of Gilead, Gad, and Reuben; he also conquered parts of Manasseh from the Aroer River in the valley of the Arnon as far as Gilead and Bashan.

34.verse: The rest of Jehu’s activities are recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Israel.

35.verse: When Jehu died, he was buried in Samaria; and his son Jehoahaz became the new king.

36.verse: In all, Jehu reigned as king of Israel, in Samaria, for twenty-eight years.

1.verse: When Athaliah, the mother of King Ahaziah of Judah, learned that her son was dead, she killed all of his children,

2.verse: except for his year-old son Joash. Joash was rescued by his Aunt Jehosheba, who was a sister of King Ahaziah (for she was a daughter of King Jehoram, Ahaziah’s father). She stole him away from among the rest of the king’s children who were waiting to be slain and hid him and his nurse in a storeroom of the Temple.* They lived there for six years while Athaliah reigned as queen.
