4.verse: In the seventh year of Queen Athaliah’s reign, Jehoiada the priest summoned the officers of the palace guard and the queen’s bodyguard. He met them in the Temple, swore them to secrecy, and showed them the king’s son.

5.verse: Then he gave them their instructions: “A third of those who are on duty on the Sabbath are to guard the palace.

6.verse: The other two-thirds shall stand guard at the Temple; surround the king, weapons in hand, and kill anyone who tries to break through. Stay with the king at all times.”

7.verse: The other two-thirds shall stand guard at the Temple; surround the king, weapons in hand, and kill anyone who tries to break through. Stay with the king at all times.”

8.verse: The other two-thirds shall stand guard at the Temple; surround the king, weapons in hand, and kill anyone who tries to break through. Stay with the king at all times.”

9.verse: So the officers followed Jehoiada’s instructions. They brought to Jehoiada the men who were going off duty on the Sabbath and those who were coming on duty,

10.verse: and he armed them from the Temple’s supply of spears and shields that had belonged to King David.

11.verse: The guards, with weapons ready, stood across the front of the sanctuary and surrounded the altar, which was near Joash’s hideaway.

12.verse: Then Jehoiada brought out the young prince and put the crown upon his head and gave him a copy of the Ten Commandments, and anointed him as king. Then everyone clapped and shouted, “Long live the king!”

13.verse: When Athaliah heard all the noise, she ran into the Temple and saw the new king standing beside the pillar, as was the custom at times of coronation, surrounded by her bodyguard and many trumpeters; and everyone was rejoicing and blowing trumpets. “Treason! Treason!” she screamed, and began to tear her clothes.

14.verse: When Athaliah heard all the noise, she ran into the Temple and saw the new king standing beside the pillar, as was the custom at times of coronation, surrounded by her bodyguard and many trumpeters; and everyone was rejoicing and blowing trumpets. “Treason! Treason!” she screamed, and began to tear her clothes.

15.verse: “Get her out of here,” shouted Jehoiada to the officers of the guard. “Don’t kill her here in the Temple. But kill anyone who tries to come to her rescue.”

16.verse: So they dragged her to the palace stables and killed her there.

17.verse: Jehoiada made a treaty between the Lord, the king, and the people, that they would be the Lord’s people. He also made a contract between the king and the people.

18.verse: Everyone went over to the temple of Baal and tore it down, breaking the altars and images and killing Mattan, the priest of Baal, in front of the altar. And Jehoiada set guards at the Temple of the Lord.

19.verse: Then he and the officers and the guard and all the people led the king from the Temple, past the guardhouse, and into the palace. And he sat upon the king’s throne.

20.verse: So everyone was happy, and the city settled back into quietness after Athaliah’s death.

21.verse: Joash was seven years old when he became king.

1.verse: It was seven years after Jehu had become the king of Israel that Joash became king of Judah. He reigned in Jerusalem for forty years. (His mother was Zibiah, from Beersheba.)

2.verse: All his life Joash did what was right because Jehoiada the High Priest instructed him.

3.verse: Yet even so he didn’t destroy the shrines on the hills—the people still sacrificed and burned incense there.

4.verse: One day King Joash said to Jehoiada, “The Temple building needs repairing. Whenever anyone brings a contribution to the Lord, whether it is a regular assessment or some special gift, use it to pay for whatever repairs are needed.”

5.verse: One day King Joash said to Jehoiada, “The Temple building needs repairing. Whenever anyone brings a contribution to the Lord, whether it is a regular assessment or some special gift, use it to pay for whatever repairs are needed.”

6.verse: But in the twenty-third year of his reign the Temple was still in disrepair.

7.verse: So Joash called for Jehoiada and the other priests and asked them, “Why haven’t you done anything about the Temple? Now don’t use any more money for your own needs; from now on it must all be spent on getting the Temple into good condition.”

8.verse: So the priests agreed to set up a special repair fund that would not go through their hands, lest it be diverted to care for their personal needs.

9.verse: Jehoiada the priest bored a hole in the lid of a large chest and set it on the right-hand side of the altar at the Temple entrance. The doorkeepers put all of the people’s contributions into it.

10.verse: Whenever the chest became full, the king’s financial secretary and the High Priest counted it, put it into bags,

11.verse: and gave it to the construction superintendents to pay the carpenters, stonemasons, quarrymen, timber dealers, and stone merchants, and to buy the other materials needed to repair the Temple of the Lord.

12.verse: and gave it to the construction superintendents to pay the carpenters, stonemasons, quarrymen, timber dealers, and stone merchants, and to buy the other materials needed to repair the Temple of the Lord.

13.verse: It was not used to buy silver cups, gold snuffers, bowls, trumpets, or similar articles, but only for repairs to the building.

14.verse: It was not used to buy silver cups, gold snuffers, bowls, trumpets, or similar articles, but only for repairs to the building.

15.verse: No accounting was required from the construction superintendents, for they were honest and faithful men.

16.verse: However, the money that was contributed for guilt offerings and sin offerings was given to the priests for their own use. It was not put into the chest.

17.verse: About this time, King Hazael of Syria went to war against Gath and captured it; then he moved on toward Jerusalem to attack it.

18.verse: King Joash took all the sacred objects that his ancestors—Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, and Ahaziah, the kings of Judah—had dedicated, along with what he himself had dedicated, and all the gold in the treasuries of the Temple and the palace, and sent it to Hazael. So Hazael called off the attack.

19.verse: The rest of the history of Joash is recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Judah.

20.verse: But his officers plotted against him and assassinated him in his royal residence at Millo on the road to Silla.

21.verse: The assassins were Jozachar, the son of Shimeath, and Jehozabad, the son of Shomer—both trusted aides. He was buried in the royal cemetery in Jerusalem, and his son Amaziah became the new king.

1.verse: Jehoahaz (the son of Jehu) began a seventeen-year reign over Israel during the twenty-third year of the reign of King Joash of Judah.

2.verse: But he was an evil king, and he followed the wicked paths of Jeroboam, who had caused Israel to sin.

3.verse: So the Lord was very angry with Israel, and he continually allowed King Hazael of Syria and his son Ben-hadad to conquer them.

4.verse: But Jehoahaz prayed for the Lord’s help, and the Lord listened to him; for the Lord saw how terribly the king of Syria was oppressing Israel.

5.verse: So the Lord raised up leaders among the Israelis to rescue them from the tyranny of the Syrians; and then Israel lived in safety again as they had in former days.

6.verse: But they continued to sin, following the evil ways of Jeroboam; and they continued to worship the goddess Asherah at Samaria.

7.verse: Finally the Lord reduced Jehoahaz’s army to fifty mounted troops, ten chariots, and ten thousand infantry; for the king of Syria had destroyed the others as though they were dust beneath his feet.

8.verse: The rest of the history of Jehoahaz is recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Israel.

9.verse: Jehoahaz died and was buried in Samaria, and his son Joash reigned in Samaria for sixteen years. He came to the throne in the thirty-seventh year of the reign of King Joash of Judah.

10.verse: Jehoahaz died and was buried in Samaria, and his son Joash reigned in Samaria for sixteen years. He came to the throne in the thirty-seventh year of the reign of King Joash of Judah.

11.verse: But he was an evil man, for, like Jeroboam, he encouraged the people to worship idols and led them into sin.

12.verse: The rest of the history of the reign of Joash, including his wars against King Amaziah of Judah, are written in The Annals of the Kings of Israel.

13.verse: Joash died and was buried in Samaria with the other kings of Israel; and Jeroboam II became the new king.

14.verse: When Elisha was in his last illness, King Joash visited him and wept over him. “My father! My father! You are the strength of Israel!” he cried.

15.verse: Elisha told him, “Get a bow and some arrows,” and he did.

16.verse: “Open that eastern window,” he instructed. Then he told the king to put his hand upon the bow, and Elisha laid his own hands upon the king’s hands. “Shoot!” Elisha commanded, and he did. Then Elisha proclaimed, “This is the Lord’s arrow, full of victory over Syria; for you will completely conquer the Syrians at Aphek.

17.verse: “Open that eastern window,” he instructed. Then he told the king to put his hand upon the bow, and Elisha laid his own hands upon the king’s hands. “Shoot!” Elisha commanded, and he did. Then Elisha proclaimed, “This is the Lord’s arrow, full of victory over Syria; for you will completely conquer the Syrians at Aphek.

18.verse: Now pick up the other arrows and strike them against the floor.” So the king picked them up and struck the floor three times.

19.verse: But the prophet was angry with him. “You should have struck the floor five or six times,” he exclaimed, “for then you would have beaten Syria until they were entirely destroyed; now you will be victorious only three times.”

20.verse: So Elisha died and was buried. In those days bandit gangs of Moabites used to invade the land each spring. Once some men who were burying a friend spied these marauders so they hastily threw his body into the tomb of Elisha. And as soon as the body touched Elisha’s bones, the dead man revived and jumped to his feet!

21.verse: So Elisha died and was buried. In those days bandit gangs of Moabites used to invade the land each spring. Once some men who were burying a friend spied these marauders so they hastily threw his body into the tomb of Elisha. And as soon as the body touched Elisha’s bones, the dead man revived and jumped to his feet!

22.verse: King Hazael of Syria had oppressed Israel during the entire reign of King Jehoahaz.

23.verse: But the Lord was gracious to the people of Israel, and they were not totally destroyed. For God pitied them, and also he was honoring his contract with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. And this is still true.

24.verse: Then King Hazael of Syria died, and his son Ben-hadad reigned in his place.

25.verse: King Joash of Israel (the son of Jehoahaz) was successful on three occasions in reconquering the cities that his father had lost to Ben-hadad.

1.verse: During the second year of the reign of King Joash of Israel, King Amaziah began his reign over Judah.

2.verse: Amaziah was twenty-five years old at the time, and he reigned in Jerusalem for twenty-nine years. (His mother was Jehoaddin, a native of Jerusalem.)

3.verse: He was a good king in the Lord’s sight, though not quite like his ancestor David; but he was as good a king as his father Joash.

4.verse: However, he didn’t destroy the shrines on the hills, so the people still sacrificed and burned incense there.

5.verse: As soon as he had a firm grip on the kingdom, he killed the men who had assassinated his father;

6.verse: but he didn’t kill their children, for the Lord had commanded through the law of Moses that fathers shall not be killed for their children, nor children for the sins of their fathers: everyone must pay the penalty for his own sins.

7.verse: Once Amaziah killed ten thousand Edomites in Salt Valley; he also conquered Sela and changed its name to Joktheel, as it is called to this day.

8.verse: One day he sent a message to King Joash of Israel (the son of Jehoahaz and the grandson of Jehu), daring him to mobilize his army and come out and fight.

9.verse: But King Joash replied, “The thistle of Lebanon demanded of the mighty cedar tree, ‘Give your daughter to be a wife for my son.’ But just then a wild animal passed by and stepped on the thistle and trod it into the ground!

10.verse: You have destroyed Edom and are very proud about it; but my advice to you is, be content with your glory and stay home! Why provoke disaster for both yourself and Judah?”

11.verse: But Amaziah refused to listen, so King Joash of Israel mustered his army. The battle began at Beth-shemesh, one of the cities of Judah,

12.verse: and Judah was defeated and the army fled home.

13.verse: King Amaziah was captured, and the army of Israel marched on Jerusalem and broke down its wall from the Gate of Ephraim to the Corner Gate, a distance of about six hundred feet.

14.verse: King Joash took many hostages and all the gold and silver from the Temple and palace treasury, also the gold cups. Then he returned to Samaria.

15.verse: The rest of the history of Joash and his war with King Amaziah of Judah are recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Israel.

16.verse: When Joash died, he was buried in Samaria with the other kings of Israel. And his son Jeroboam became the new king.

17.verse: Amaziah lived fifteen years longer than Joash,

18.verse: and the rest of his biography is recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Judah.

19.verse: There was a plot against his life in Jerusalem, and he fled to Lachish; but his enemies sent assassins and killed him there.

20.verse: His body was returned on horses, and he was buried in the royal cemetery, in the City of David section of Jerusalem.

21.verse: Then his son Azariah became the new king at the age of sixteen.

22.verse: After his father’s death, he built Elath and restored it to Judah.

23.verse: Meanwhile, over in Israel, Jeroboam II had become king during the fifteenth year of the reign of King Amaziah of Judah. Jeroboam’s reign lasted forty-one years.

24.verse: But he was as evil as Jeroboam I (the son of Nebat), who had led Israel into the sin of worshiping idols.

25.verse: Jeroboam II recovered the lost territories of Israel between Hamath and the Dead Sea, just as the Lord God of Israel had predicted through Jonah (son of Amittai) the prophet from Gathhepher.

26.verse: For the Lord saw the bitter plight of Israel—she had no one to help her.

27.verse: And he had not said that he would blot out the name of Israel, so he used King Jeroboam II to save her.

28.verse: The rest of Jeroboam’s biography—all that he did, and his great power, and his wars, and how he recovered Damascus and Hamath (which had been captured by Judah)—is recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Israel.

29.verse: When Jeroboam II died, he was buried with the other kings of Israel, and his son Zechariah became the new king of Israel.

1.verse: New king of Judah: Azariah Father’s name: Amaziah, the former king His age at the beginning of his reign: 16 years old Length of reign: 52 years, in Jerusalem Mother’s name: Jecoliah of Jerusalem Reigning in Israel at that time: King Jeroboam, who had been the king there for 27 years

2.verse: New king of Judah: Azariah Father’s name: Amaziah, the former king His age at the beginning of his reign: 16 years old Length of reign: 52 years, in Jerusalem Mother’s name: Jecoliah of Jerusalem Reigning in Israel at that time: King Jeroboam, who had been the king there for 27 years

3.verse: Azariah was a good king, and he pleased the Lord just as his father Amaziah had.

4.verse: But like his predecessors, he didn’t destroy the shrines on the hills where the people sacrificed and burned incense.

5.verse: Because of this the Lord struck him with leprosy, which lasted until the day of his death; so he lived in a house by himself. And his son Jotham was the acting king.

6.verse: The rest of the history of Azariah is recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Judah.

7.verse: When Azariah died, he was buried with his ancestors in the City of David, and his son Jotham became king.

8.verse: New king of Israel: Zechariah Father’s name: Jeroboam Length of reign: 6 months, in Samaria Reigning in Judah at that time: King Azariah, who had been the king there for 38 years

9.verse: But Zechariah was an evil king in the Lord’s sight, just like his ancestors. Like Jeroboam I (the son of Nebat), he encouraged Israel in the sin of worshiping idols.

10.verse: Then Shallum (the son of Jabesh) conspired against him and assassinated him at Ibleam and took the crown himself.

11.verse: The rest of the history of Zechariah’s reign is found in The Annals of the Kings of Israel.

12.verse: (So the Lord’s statement to Jehu came true, that Jehu’s son, grandson, and great-grandson would be kings of Israel.)

13.verse: New king of Israel: Shallum Father’s name: Jabesh Length of reign: 1 month, in Samaria Reigning in Judah at that time: King Uzziah, who had been the king there for 39 years

14.verse: One month after Shallum became king, Menahem (the son of Gadi) came to Samaria from Tirzah and assassinated him and took the throne.

15.verse: Additional details about King Shallum and his conspiracy are recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Israel.

16.verse: Menahem destroyed the city of Tappuah and the surrounding countryside, for its citizens refused to accept him as their king; he killed the entire population and ripped open the pregnant women.

17.verse: New king of Israel: Menahem Length of reign: 10 years, in Samaria Reigning in Judah at that time: King Azariah, who had been the king there for 39 years

18.verse: But Menahem was an evil king. He worshiped idols, as King Jeroboam I had done so long before, and he led the people of Israel into grievous sin.

19.verse: Then King Pul of Assyria invaded the land; but King Menahem bought him off with a gift of $2,000,000, so he turned around and returned home. Menahem extorted the money from the rich, assessing each one $2,000 in the form of a special tax.

20.verse: Then King Pul of Assyria invaded the land; but King Menahem bought him off with a gift of $2,000,000, so he turned around and returned home. Menahem extorted the money from the rich, assessing each one $2,000 in the form of a special tax.

21.verse: The rest of the history of King Menahem is written in The Annals of the Kings of Israel.

22.verse: When he died, his son Pekahiah became the new king.

23.verse: New king of Israel: Pekahiah Father’s name: King Menahem Length of reign: 2 years, in Samaria Reigning in Judah at that time: King Azariah, who had been the king there for 50 years

24.verse: But Pekahiah was an evil king, and he continued the idol worship begun by Jeroboam I (son of Nebat) who led Israel down that evil trail.

25.verse: Then Pekah (son of Remaliah), the commanding general of his army, conspired against him with fifty men from Gilead and assassinated him in the palace at Samaria (Argob and Arieh were also slain in the revolt). So Pekah became the new king.

26.verse: The rest of the history of King Pekahiah is recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Israel.

27.verse: New king of Israel: Pekah Father’s name: Remaliah Length of reign: 20 years, in Samaria Reigning in Judah at that time: King Azariah, who had been the king there for 52 years

28.verse: Pekah, too, was an evil king, and he continued in the example of Jeroboam I (son of Nebat), who led all of Israel into the sin of worshiping idols.

29.verse: It was during his reign that King Tiglath-pileser led an attack against Israel. He captured the cities of Ijon, Abel-beth-maacah, Janoah, Kedesh, Hazor, Gilead, Galilee, and all the land of Naphtali; and he took the people away to Assyria as captives.

30.verse: Then Hoshea (the son of Elah) plotted against Pekah and assassinated him; and he took the throne for himself. New king of Israel: Hoshea Reigning in Judah at that time: King Jotham (son of Uzziah), who had been the king there for 20 years

31.verse: The rest of the history of Pekah’s reign is recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Israel.

32.verse: New king of Judah: Jotham Father’s name: King Uzziah His age at the beginning of his reign: 25 years old Length of reign: 16 years, in Jerusalem Mother’s name: Jerusha (daughter of Zadok) Reigning in Israel at that time: King Pekah (son of Remaliah), who had been the king there for 2 years

33.verse: New king of Judah: Jotham Father’s name: King Uzziah His age at the beginning of his reign: 25 years old Length of reign: 16 years, in Jerusalem Mother’s name: Jerusha (daughter of Zadok) Reigning in Israel at that time: King Pekah (son of Remaliah), who had been the king there for 2 years

34.verse: Generally speaking, Jotham was a good king. Like his father Uzziah, he followed the Lord. But he didn’t destroy the shrines on the hills where the people sacrificed and burned incense. It was during King Jotham’s reign that the upper gate of the Temple of the Lord was built.

35.verse: Generally speaking, Jotham was a good king. Like his father Uzziah, he followed the Lord. But he didn’t destroy the shrines on the hills where the people sacrificed and burned incense. It was during King Jotham’s reign that the upper gate of the Temple of the Lord was built.

36.verse: The rest of Jotham’s history is written in The Annals of the Kings of Judah.

37.verse: In those days the Lord caused King Rezin of Syria and King Pekah of Israel to attack Judah.

38.verse: When Jotham died he was buried with the other kings of Judah in the royal cemetery, in the City of David section of Jerusalem. Then his son Ahaz became the new king.

1.verse: New king of Judah: Ahaz Father’s name: Jotham His age at the beginning of his reign: 20 years old Length of reign: 16 years, in Jerusalem Character of his reign: evil Reigning in Israel at that time: King Pekah (son of Remaliah), who had been the king there for 17 years

2.verse: But he did not follow the Lord as his ancestor David had;

3.verse: he was as wicked as the kings of Israel. He even killed his own son by offering him as a burnt sacrifice to the gods, following the heathen customs of the nations around Judah—nations that the Lord destroyed when the people of Israel entered the land.

4.verse: He also sacrificed and burned incense at the shrines on the hills and at the numerous altars in the groves of trees.

5.verse: Then King Rezin of Syria and King Pekah (son of Remaliah) of Israel declared war on Ahaz and besieged Jerusalem; but they did not conquer it.

6.verse: However, at that time King Rezin of Syria recovered the city of Elath for Syria; he drove out the Jews and sent Syrians to live there, as they do to this day.

7.verse: King Ahaz sent a messenger to King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria, begging him to help him fight the attacking armies of Syria and Israel.

8.verse: Ahaz took the silver and gold from the Temple and from the royal vaults and sent it as a payment to the Assyrian king.

9.verse: So the Assyrians attacked Damascus, the capital of Syria. They took away the population of the city as captives, resettling them in Kir, and King Rezin of Syria was killed.

10.verse: King Ahaz now went to Damascus to meet with King Tiglath-pileser, and while he was there he noticed an unusual altar in a heathen temple. He jotted down its dimensions and made a sketch and sent it back to Uriah the priest with a detailed description.

11.verse: Uriah built one just like it by following these directions and had it ready for the king, who, upon his return from Damascus, inaugurated it with an offering.

12.verse: Uriah built one just like it by following these directions and had it ready for the king, who, upon his return from Damascus, inaugurated it with an offering.

13.verse: The king presented a burnt offering and a grain offering, poured a drink offering over it, and sprinkled the blood of peace offerings upon it.

14.verse: Then he removed the old bronze altar from the front of the Temple (it had stood between the Temple entrance and the new altar), and placed it on the north side of the new altar.

15.verse: He instructed Uriah the priest to use the new altar for the sacrifices of burnt offering, the evening grain offering, the king’s burnt offering and grain offering, and the offerings of the people, including their drink offerings. The blood from the burnt offerings and sacrifices was also to be sprinkled over the new altar. So the old altar was used only for purposes of divination. “The old bronze altar,” he said, “will be only for my personal use.”

16.verse: Uriah the priest did as King Ahaz instructed him.

17.verse: Then the king dismantled the wheeled stands in the Temple, removed their crosspieces and the water vats they supported, and removed the great tank from the backs of the bronze oxen and placed it upon the stone pavement.

18.verse: In deference to the king of Assyria he also removed the festive passageway he had constructed between the palace and the Temple.

19.verse: The rest of the history of the reign of King Ahaz is recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Judah.

20.verse: When Ahaz died he was buried in the royal cemetery, in the City of David sector of Jerusalem, and his son Hezekiah became the new king.

1.verse: New king of Israel: Hoshea Father’s name: Elah Length of reign: 9 years, in Samaria Character of his reign: evil—but not as bad as some of the other kings of Israel Reigning in Judah at that time: King Ahaz, who had been the king there for 12 years

2.verse: New king of Israel: Hoshea Father’s name: Elah Length of reign: 9 years, in Samaria Character of his reign: evil—but not as bad as some of the other kings of Israel Reigning in Judah at that time: King Ahaz, who had been the king there for 12 years

3.verse: King Shalmaneser of Assyria attacked and defeated King Hoshea, so Israel had to pay heavy annual taxes to Assyria.

4.verse: Then Hoshea conspired against the king of Assyria by asking King So of Egypt to help him shake free of Assyria’s power, but this treachery was discovered. At the same time he refused to pay the annual tribute to Assyria. So the king of Assyria put him in prison and in chains for his rebellion.

5.verse: Now the land of Israel was filled with Assyrian troops for three years besieging Samaria, the capital city of Israel.

6.verse: Finally, in the ninth year of King Hoshea’s reign, Samaria fell and the people of Israel were exiled to Assyria. They were placed in colonies in the city of Halah and along the banks of the Habor River in Gozan, and among the cities of the Medes.

7.verse: This disaster came upon the nation of Israel because the people worshiped other gods, thus sinning against the Lord their God who had brought them safely out of their slavery in Egypt.

8.verse: They had followed the evil customs of the nations which the Lord had cast out from before them.

9.verse: The people of Israel had also secretly done many things that were wrong, and they had built altars to other gods throughout the land.

10.verse: They had placed obelisks and idols at the top of every hill and under every green tree;

11.verse: and they had burned incense to the gods of the very nations which the Lord had cleared out of the land when Israel came in. So the people of Israel had done many evil things, and the Lord was very angry.

12.verse: Yes, they worshiped idols, despite the Lord’s specific and repeated warnings.

13.verse: Again and again the Lord had sent prophets to warn both Israel and Judah to turn from their evil ways; he had warned them to obey his commandments which he had given to their ancestors through these prophets,

14.verse: but Israel wouldn’t listen. The people were as stubborn as their ancestors and refused to believe in the Lord their God.

15.verse: They rejected his laws and the covenant he had made with their ancestors, and despised all his warnings. In their foolishness they worshiped heathen idols despite the Lord’s stern warnings.

16.verse: They defied all the commandments of the Lord their God and made two calves from molten gold. They made detestable, shameful idols and worshiped Baal and the sun, moon, and stars.

17.verse: They even burned their own sons and daughters to death on the altars of Molech; they consulted fortune-tellers and used magic and sold themselves to evil. So the Lord was very angry.

18.verse: He swept them from his sight until only the tribe of Judah remained in the land.

19.verse: But even Judah refused to obey the commandments of the Lord their God; they too walked in the same evil paths as Israel had.

20.verse: So the Lord rejected all the descendants of Jacob. He punished them by delivering them to their attackers until they were destroyed.

21.verse: For Israel split off from the kingdom of David and chose Jeroboam I (the son of Nebat) as its king. Then Jeroboam drew Israel away from following the Lord. He made them sin a great sin,

22.verse: and the people of Israel never quit doing the evil things that Jeroboam led them into,

23.verse: until the Lord finally swept them away, just as all his prophets had warned would happen. So Israel was carried off to the land of Assyria where they remain to this day.

24.verse: And the king of Assyria transported colonies of people from Babylon, Cuthah, Avva, Hamath, and Sepharvaim and resettled them in the cities of Samaria, replacing the people of Israel. So the Assyrians took over Samaria and the other cities of Israel.

25.verse: But since these Assyrian colonists did not worship the Lord when they first arrived, the Lord sent lions among them to kill some of them.

26.verse: Then they sent a message to the king of Assyria: “We colonists here in Israel don’t know the laws of the god of the land, and he has sent lions among us to destroy us because we have not worshiped him.”

27.verse: The king of Assyria then decreed that one of the exiled priests from Samaria should return to Israel and teach the new residents the laws of the god of the land. So one of them returned to Bethel and taught the colonists from Babylon how to worship the Lord.

28.verse: The king of Assyria then decreed that one of the exiled priests from Samaria should return to Israel and teach the new residents the laws of the god of the land. So one of them returned to Bethel and taught the colonists from Babylon how to worship the Lord.

29.verse: But these foreigners also worshiped their own gods. They placed them in the shrines on the hills near their cities.

30.verse: Those from Babylon worshiped idols of their god Succoth-benoth; those from Cuth worshiped their god Nergal; and the men of Hamath worshiped Ashima.

31.verse: The gods Nibhaz and Tartak were worshiped by the Avvites, and the people from Sephar even burned their own children on the altars of their gods Adrammelech and Anammelech.

32.verse: They also worshiped the Lord, and they appointed from among themselves priests to sacrifice to the Lord on the hilltop altars.

33.verse: But they continued to follow the religious customs of the nations from which they came.

34.verse: And this is still going on among them today—they follow their former practices instead of truly worshiping the Lord or obeying the laws he gave to the descendants of Jacob (whose name was later changed to Israel).

35.verse: For the Lord had made a contract with them—that they were never to worship or make sacrifices to any heathen gods. They were to worship only the Lord who had brought them out of the land of Egypt with such tremendous miracles and power.

36.verse: For the Lord had made a contract with them—that they were never to worship or make sacrifices to any heathen gods. They were to worship only the Lord who had brought them out of the land of Egypt with such tremendous miracles and power.

37.verse: The descendants of Jacob were to obey all of God’s laws and never worship other gods.

38.verse: For God had said, “You must never forget the covenant I made with you; never worship other gods.

39.verse: You must worship only the Lord; he will save you from all your enemies.”

40.verse: But Israel didn’t listen, and the people continued to worship other gods.

41.verse: These colonists from Babylon worshiped the Lord, yes—but they also worshiped their idols. And to this day their descendants do the same thing.

1.verse: New king of Judah: Hezekiah Father’s name: Ahaz His age at the beginning of his reign: 25 years old Length of reign: 29 years, in Jerusalem Mother’s name: Abi (daughter of Zechariah) Character of his reign: good (similar to that of his ancestor David) Reigning in Israel at that time: King Hoshea (son of Elah), who had been the king there for 3 years

2.verse: New king of Judah: Hezekiah Father’s name: Ahaz His age at the beginning of his reign: 25 years old Length of reign: 29 years, in Jerusalem Mother’s name: Abi (daughter of Zechariah) Character of his reign: good (similar to that of his ancestor David) Reigning in Israel at that time: King Hoshea (son of Elah), who had been the king there for 3 years

3.verse: New king of Judah: Hezekiah Father’s name: Ahaz His age at the beginning of his reign: 25 years old Length of reign: 29 years, in Jerusalem Mother’s name: Abi (daughter of Zechariah) Character of his reign: good (similar to that of his ancestor David) Reigning in Israel at that time: King Hoshea (son of Elah), who had been the king there for 3 years

4.verse: He removed the shrines on the hills, broke down the obelisks, knocked down the shameful idols of Asherah, and broke up the bronze serpent that Moses had made, because the people of Israel had begun to worship it by burning incense to it; even though, as King Hezekiah pointed out to them, it was merely a piece of bronze.

5.verse: He trusted very strongly in the Lord God of Israel. In fact, none of the kings before or after him were as close to God as he was.

6.verse: For he followed the Lord in everything, and carefully obeyed all of God’s commands to Moses.

7.verse: So the Lord was with him and prospered everything he did. Then he rebelled against the king of Assyria and refused to pay tribute any longer.

8.verse: He also conquered the Philistines as far distant as Gaza and its suburbs, destroying cities both large and small.

9.verse: It was during the fourth year of his reign (which was the seventh year of the reign of King Hoshea in Israel) that King Shalmaneser of Assyria attacked Israel and began a siege on the city of Samaria.

10.verse: Three years later (during the sixth year of the reign of King Hezekiah and the ninth year of the reign of King Hoshea of Israel) Samaria fell.

11.verse: It was at that time that the king of Assyria transported the Israelis to Assyria and put them in colonies in the city of Halath and along the banks of the Habor River in Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes.

12.verse: For they had refused to listen to the Lord their God or to do what he wanted them to do. Instead, they had transgressed his covenant and disobeyed all the laws given to them by Moses the servant of the Lord.

13.verse: Later, during the fourteenth year of the reign of King Hezekiah, King Sennacherib of Assyria besieged and captured all the fortified cities of Judah.

14.verse: King Hezekiah sued for peace and sent this message to the king of Assyria at Lachish: “I have done wrong. I will pay whatever tribute you demand if you will only go away.” The king of Assyria then demanded a settlement of $1,500,000.

15.verse: To gather this amount, King Hezekiah used all the silver stored in the Temple and in the palace treasury.

16.verse: He even stripped off the gold from the Temple doors, and from the doorposts he had overlaid with gold, and gave it all to the Assyrian king.

17.verse: Nevertheless the king of Assyria sent his field marshal, his chief treasurer, and his chief of staff from Lachish with a great army; and they camped along the highway beside the field where cloth was bleached, near the conduit of the upper pool.

18.verse: They demanded that King Hezekiah come out to speak to them, but instead he sent a truce delegation of the following men: Eliakim, his business manager; Shebnah, his secretary; and Joah, his royal historian.

19.verse: Then the Assyrian general sent this message to King Hezekiah: “The great king of Assyria says, ‘No one can save you from my power!

20.verse: You need more than mere promises of help before rebelling against me. But which of your allies will give you more than words? Egypt? If you lean on Egypt, you will find her to be a stick that breaks beneath your weight and pierces your hand. The Egyptian Pharaoh is totally unreliable!

21.verse: You need more than mere promises of help before rebelling against me. But which of your allies will give you more than words? Egypt? If you lean on Egypt, you will find her to be a stick that breaks beneath your weight and pierces your hand. The Egyptian Pharaoh is totally unreliable!

22.verse: And if you say, “We’re trusting the Lord to rescue us”—just remember that he is the very one whose hilltop altars you’ve destroyed. For you require everyone to worship at the altar in Jerusalem!’

23.verse: I’ll tell you what: Make a bet with my master, the king of Assyria! If you have two thousand men left who can ride horses, we’ll furnish the horses!

24.verse: And with an army as small as yours, you are no threat to even the least lieutenant in charge of the smallest contingent in my master’s army. Even if Egypt supplies you with horses and chariots, it will do no good.

25.verse: And do you think we have come here on our own? No! The Lord sent us and told us, ‘Go and destroy this nation!’”

26.verse: Then Eliakim, Shebnah, and Joah said to them, “Please speak in Aramaic, for we understand it. Don’t use Hebrew, for the people standing on the walls will hear you.”

27.verse: But the Assyrian general replied, “Has my master sent me to speak only to you and to your master? Hasn’t he sent me to the people on the walls too? For they are doomed with you to eat their own excrement and drink their own urine!”

28.verse: Then the Assyrian ambassador shouted in Hebrew to the people on the wall, “Listen to the great king of Assyria!

29.verse: ‘Don’t let King Hezekiah fool you. He will never be able to save you from my power.

30.verse: Don’t let him fool you into trusting in the Lord to rescue you.

31.verse: Don’t listen to King Hezekiah. Surrender! You can live in peace here in your own land until I take you to another land just like this one—with plentiful crops, grain, grapes, olive trees, and honey. All of this instead of death! Don’t listen to King Hezekiah when he tries to persuade you that the Lord will deliver you.

32.verse: Don’t listen to King Hezekiah. Surrender! You can live in peace here in your own land until I take you to another land just like this one—with plentiful crops, grain, grapes, olive trees, and honey. All of this instead of death! Don’t listen to King Hezekiah when he tries to persuade you that the Lord will deliver you.

33.verse: Have any of the gods of the other nations ever delivered their people from the king of Assyria?

34.verse: What happened to the gods of Hamath, Arpad, Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah? Did they rescue Samaria?

35.verse: What god has ever been able to save any nation from my power? So what makes you think the Lord can save Jerusalem?’”

36.verse: But the people on the wall remained silent, for the king had instructed them to say nothing.

37.verse: Then Eliakim (son of Hilkiah) the business manager, and Shebnah the king’s secretary, and Joah (son of Asaph) the historian went to King Hezekiah with their clothes torn and told him what the Assyrian general had said.

1.verse: When King Hezekiah heard their report, he tore his clothes and put on sackcloth and went into the Temple to pray.

2.verse: Then he told Eliakim, Shebnah, and some of the older priests to clothe themselves in sackcloth and to go to Isaiah (son of Amoz), the prophet, with this message:

3.verse: “King Hezekiah says, ‘This is a day of trouble, insult, and dishonor. It is as when a child is ready to be born, but the mother has no strength to deliver it.

4.verse: Yet perhaps the Lord your God has heard the Assyrian general defying the living God and will rebuke him. Oh, pray for the few of us who are left.’”

5.verse: Isaiah replied, “The Lord says, ‘Tell your master not to be troubled by the sneers these Assyrians have made against me.’

6.verse: Isaiah replied, “The Lord says, ‘Tell your master not to be troubled by the sneers these Assyrians have made against me.’

7.verse: For the king of Assyria will receive bad news from home and will decide to return; and the Lord will see to it that he is killed when he arrives there.”

8.verse: Then the Assyrian general returned to his king at Libnah (for he received word that he had left Lachish).

9.verse: Soon afterwards news reached the king that King Tirhakah of Ethiopia was coming to attack him. Before leaving to meet the attack, he sent back this message to King Hezekiah:

10.verse: “Don’t be fooled by that god you trust in. Don’t believe it when he says that I won’t conquer Jerusalem.

11.verse: You know perfectly well what the kings of Assyria have done wherever they have gone; they have completely destroyed everything. Why would you be any different?

12.verse: Have the gods of the other nations delivered them—such nations as Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and Eden in the land of Telassar? The former kings of Assyria destroyed them all!

13.verse: What happened to the king of Hamoth and the king of Arpad? What happened to the kings of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah?”

14.verse: Hezekiah took the letter from the messengers, read it, and went over to the Temple and spread it out before the Lord.

15.verse: Then he prayed this prayer: “O Lord God of Israel, sitting on your throne high above the angels, you alone are the God of all the kingdoms of the earth. You created the heavens and the earth.

16.verse: Bend low, O Lord, and listen. Open your eyes, O Lord, and see. Listen to this man’s defiance of the living God.

17.verse: Lord, it is true that the kings of Assyria have destroyed all those nations

18.verse: and have burned their idol-gods. But they weren’t gods at all; they were destroyed because they were only things that men had made of wood and stone.

19.verse: O Lord our God, we plead with you to save us from his power; then all the kingdoms of the earth will know that you alone are God.”

20.verse: Then Isaiah sent this message to Hezekiah: “The Lord God of Israel says, ‘I have heard you!

21.verse: And this is my reply to King Sennacherib: The virgin daughter of Zion isn’t afraid of you! The daughter of Jerusalem scorns and mocks at you.

22.verse: Whom have you defied and blasphemed? And toward whom have you felt so cocky? It is the Holy One of Israel!

23.verse: “‘You have boasted, “My chariots have conquered the highest mountains, yes, the peaks of Lebanon. I have cut down the tallest cedars and choicest cypress trees and have conquered the farthest borders.

24.verse: I have been refreshed at many conquered wells, and I destroyed the strength of Egypt just by walking by!”

25.verse: “‘Why haven’t you realized long before this that it is I, the Lord, who lets you do these things? I decreed your conquest of all those fortified cities!

26.verse: So of course the nations you conquered had no power against you! They were like grass shriveling beneath the hot sun, and like grain blighted before it is half grown.

27.verse: I know everything about you. I know all your plans and where you are going next; and I also know the evil things you have said about me.

28.verse: And because of your arrogance against me, I am going to put a hook in your nose and a bridle in your mouth and turn you back on the road by which you came.

29.verse: And this is the proof that I will do as I have promised: This year my people will eat the volunteer wheat and use it as seed for next year’s crop; and in the third year they will have a bountiful harvest.

30.verse: “‘O my people Judah, those of you who have escaped the ravages of the siege shall become a great nation again; you shall be rooted deeply in the soil and bear fruit for God.

31.verse: A remnant of my people shall become strong in Jerusalem. The Lord is eager to cause this to happen.

32.verse: “‘And my command concerning the king of Assyria is that he shall not enter this city. He shall not stand before it with a shield, nor build a ramp against its wall, nor even shoot an arrow into it.

33.verse: He shall return by the road he came,

34.verse: for I will defend and save this city for the sake of my own name and for the sake of my servant David.’”

35.verse: That very night the Angel of the Lord killed 185,000 Assyrian troops, and dead bodies were seen all across the landscape in the morning.

36.verse: Then King Sennacherib returned to Nineveh;

37.verse: and as he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer killed him. They escaped into eastern Turkey—the land of Ararat—and his son Esarhaddon became the new king.

1.verse: Hezekiah now became deathly sick, and Isaiah the prophet went to visit him. “Set your affairs in order and prepare to die,” Isaiah told him. “The Lord says you won’t recover.”

2.verse: Hezekiah turned his face to the wall.

3.verse: “O Lord,” he pleaded, “remember how I’ve always tried to obey you and to please you in everything I do. . . . ” Then he broke down and cried.

4.verse: So before Isaiah had left the courtyard, the Lord spoke to him again.

5.verse: “Go back to Hezekiah, the leader of my people, and tell him that the Lord God of his ancestor David has heard his prayer and seen his tears. I will heal him, and three days from now he will be out of bed and at the Temple!

6.verse: I will add fifteen years to his life and save him and this city from the king of Assyria. And it will all be done for the glory of my own name and for the sake of my servant David.”

7.verse: Isaiah then instructed Hezekiah to boil some dried figs and to make a paste of them and spread it on the boil. And he recovered!

8.verse: Meanwhile, King Hezekiah had said to Isaiah, “Do a miracle to prove to me that the Lord will heal me and that I will be able to go to the Temple again three days from now.”

9.verse: “All right, the Lord will give you a proof,” Isaiah told him. “Do you want the shadow on the sundial to go forward ten points or backward ten points?”

10.verse: “The shadow always moves forward,” Hezekiah replied; “make it go backward.”

11.verse: So Isaiah asked the Lord to do this, and he caused the shadow to move ten points backward on the sundial of Ahaz!

12.verse: At that time Merodach-baladan (the son of King Baladan of Babylon) sent ambassadors with greetings and a present to Hezekiah, for he had learned of his sickness.

13.verse: Hezekiah welcomed them and showed them all his treasures—the silver, gold, spices, aromatic oils, the armory—everything.

14.verse: Then Isaiah went to King Hezekiah and asked him, “What did these men want? Where are they from?” “From far away in Babylon,” Hezekiah replied.

15.verse: “What have they seen in your palace?” Isaiah asked. And Hezekiah replied, “Everything. I showed them all my treasures.”

16.verse: Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Listen to the word of the Lord:

17.verse: The time will come when everything in this palace shall be carried to Babylon. All the treasures of your ancestors will be taken—nothing shall be left.

18.verse: Some of your own sons will be taken away and made into eunuchs who will serve in the palace of the king of Babylon.”

19.verse: “All right,” Hezekiah replied, “if this is what the Lord wants, it is good.” But he was really thinking, “At least there will be peace and security during the remainder of my own life!”

20.verse: The rest of the history of Hezekiah and his great deeds—including the pool and conduit he made and how he brought water into the city—are recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Judah.

21.verse: When he died, his son Manasseh became the new king.

9.verse: But the people did not listen to the Lord, and Manasseh enticed them to do even more evil than the surrounding nations had done, even though Jehovah had destroyed those nations for their evil ways when the people of Israel entered the land.

10.verse: Then the Lord declared through the prophets,

11.verse: “Because King Manasseh has done these evil things and is even more wicked than the Amorites who were in this land long ago, and because he has led the people of Judah into idolatry:

12.verse: I will bring such evil upon Jerusalem and Judah that the ears of those who hear about it will tingle with horror.

13.verse: I will punish Jerusalem as I did Samaria, and as I did King Ahab of Israel and his descendants. I will wipe away the people of Jerusalem as a man wipes a dish and turns it upside down to dry.

14.verse: Then I will reject even those few of my people who are left, and I will hand them over to their enemies.

15.verse: For they have done great evil and have angered me ever since I brought their ancestors from Egypt.”

16.verse: In addition to the idolatry which God hated and into which Manasseh led the people of Judah, he murdered great numbers of innocent people. And Jerusalem was filled from one end to the other with the bodies of his victims.

17.verse: The rest of the history of Manasseh’s sinful reign is recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Judah.

18.verse: When he died he was buried in the garden of his palace at Uzza, and his son Amon became the new king.

23.verse: But his aides conspired against him and killed him in the palace.

24.verse: Then a posse of civilians killed all the assassins and placed Amon’s son Josiah upon the throne.

25.verse: The rest of Amon’s biography is recorded in The Annals of the Kings of Judah.

26.verse: He was buried in a crypt in the garden of Uzza, and his son Josiah became the new king.

15.verse: She gave them this message from the Lord God of Israel: “Tell the man who sent you to me that I am going to destroy this city and its people, just as I stated in that book you read.

16.verse: She gave them this message from the Lord God of Israel: “Tell the man who sent you to me that I am going to destroy this city and its people, just as I stated in that book you read.

1.verse: Then the king sent for the elders and other leaders of Judah and Jerusalem to go to the Temple with him. So all the priests and prophets and the people, small and great, of Jerusalem and Judah gathered there at the Temple so that the king could read to them the entire book of God’s laws which had been discovered in the Temple.

So all the priests and prophets and the people, small and great, of Jerusalem and Judah gathered there at the Temple so that the king could read to them the entire book of God’s laws which had been discovered in the Temple.

3.verse: He stood beside the pillar in front of the people, and he and they made a solemn promise to the Lord to obey him at all times and to do everything the book commanded.

4.verse: Then the king instructed Hilkiah the High Priest and the rest of the priests and the guards of the Temple to destroy all the equipment used in the worship of Baal, Asherah, and the sun, moon, and stars. The king had it all burned in the fields of the Kidron Valley outside Jerusalem, and he carried the ashes to Bethel.

5.verse: He killed the heathen priests who had been appointed by the previous kings of Judah, for they had burned incense in the shrines on the hills throughout Judah and even in Jerusalem. They had also offered incense to Baal and to the sun, moon, stars, and planets.

6.verse: He removed the shameful idol of Asherah from the Temple and took it outside Jerusalem to Kidron Brook; there he burned it and beat it to dust and threw the dust on the graves of the common people.

7.verse: He also tore down the houses of male prostitution around the Temple, where the women wove robes for the Asherah idol.

8.verse: He brought back to Jerusalem the priests of the Lord, who were living in other cities of Judah, and tore down all the shrines on the hills where they had burned incense, even those as far away as Geba and Beersheba. He also destroyed the shrines at the entrance of the palace of Joshua, the former mayor of Jerusalem, located on the left side as one enters the city gate.

9.verse: However, these priests did not serve at the altar of the Lord in Jerusalem, even though they ate with the other priests.

10.verse: Then the king destroyed the altar of Topheth in the valley of the sons of Hinnom, so that no one could ever again use it to burn his son or daughter to death as a sacrifice to Molech.

11.verse: He tore down the statues of horses and chariots located near the entrance of the Temple, next to the quarters of Nathan-melech the eunuch. These had been dedicated by former kings of Judah to the sun god.

12.verse: Then he tore down the altars that the kings of Judah had built on the palace roof above the Ahaz Room. He also destroyed the altars that Manasseh had built in the two courts of the Temple; he smashed them to bits and scattered the pieces in Kidron Valley.

13.verse: Next he removed the shrines on the hills east of Jerusalem and south of Destruction Mountain. (Solomon had built these shrines for Ashtoreth, the evil goddess of the Sidonians; and for Chemosh, the evil god of Moab; and for Milcom, the evil god of the Ammonites.)

14.verse: He smashed the obelisks and cut down the shameful idols of Asherah; then he defiled these places by scattering human bones over them.

15.verse: He also tore down the altar and shrine at Bethel that Jeroboam I had made when he led Israel into sin. He crushed the stones to dust and burned the shameful idol of Asherah.

16.verse: As Josiah was looking around, he noticed several graves in the side of the mountain. He ordered his men to bring out the bones in them and to burn them there upon the altar at Bethel to defile it, just as the Lord’s prophet had declared would happen to Jeroboam’s altar.

17.verse: “What is that monument over there?” he asked. And the men of the city told him, “It is the grave of the prophet who came from Judah and proclaimed that what you have just done would happen here at the altar at Bethel!”

18.verse: So King Josiah replied, “Leave it alone. Don’t disturb his bones.” So they didn’t burn his bones or those of the prophet from Samaria.

19.verse: Josiah demolished the shrines on the hills in all of Samaria. They had been built by the various kings of Israel and had made the Lord very angry. But now he crushed them into dust, just as he had done at Bethel.

20.verse: He executed the priests of the heathen shrines upon their own altars, and he burned human bones upon the altars to defile them. Finally he returned to Jerusalem.

21.verse: The king then issued orders for his people to observe the Passover ceremonies as recorded by the Lord their God in The Book of the Covenant.

22.verse: There had not been a Passover celebration like that since the days of the judges of Israel, and there was never another like it in all the years of the kings of Israel and Judah.

23.verse: This Passover was in the eighteenth year of the reign of King Josiah, and it was celebrated in Jerusalem.

24.verse: Josiah also exterminated the mediums and wizards, and every kind of idol worship, both in Jerusalem and throughout the land. For Josiah wanted to follow all the laws that were written in the book that Hilkiah the priest had found in the Temple.

25.verse: There was no other king who so completely turned to the Lord and followed all the laws of Moses; and no king since the time of Josiah has approached his record of obedience.

26.verse: But the Lord still did not hold back his great anger against Judah, caused by the evils of King Manasseh.

27.verse: For the Lord had said, “I will destroy Judah just as I have destroyed Israel; and I will discard my chosen city of Jerusalem and the Temple that I said was mine.”

28.verse: The rest of the biography of Josiah is written in The Annals of the Kings of Judah.

30.verse: His officers took his body back in a chariot from Megiddo to Jerusalem and buried him in the grave he had selected. And his son Jehoahaz was chosen by the nation as its new king.

13.verse: The Babylonians carried home all the treasures from the Temple and the royal palace; and they cut apart all the gold bowls which King Solomon of Israel had placed in the Temple at the Lord’s directions.

14.verse: King Nebuchadnezzar took ten thousand captives from Jerusalem, including all the princes and the best of the soldiers, craftsmen, and smiths. So only the poorest and least skilled people were left in the land.

15.verse: Nebuchadnezzar took King Jehoiachin, his wives and officials, and the queen mother, to Babylon.

16.verse: He also took seven thousand of the best troops and one thousand craftsmen and smiths, all of whom were strong and fit for war.

17.verse: Then the king of Babylon appointed King Jehoiachin’s great-uncle, Mattaniah, to be the next king; and he changed his name to Zedekiah.

18.verse: New king of Judah: Zedekiah His age at the beginning of his reign: 21 years old Length of reign: 11 years, in Jerusalem Mother’s name: Hamutal (daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah) Character of his reign: evil, like that of Jehoiakim

20.verse: So the Lord finally, in his anger, destroyed the people of Jerusalem and Judah. But now King Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.

1.verse: Then King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon mobilized his entire army and laid siege to Jerusalem, arriving on March 25 of the ninth year of the reign of King Zedekiah of Judah.

2.verse: The siege continued into the eleventh year of his reign.

3.verse: The last food in the city was eaten on July 24,

4.verse: and that night the king and his troops made a hole in the inner wall and fled out toward the Arabah through a gate that lay between the double walls near the king’s garden. The Babylonian troops surrounding the city took out after him and captured him in the plains of Jericho, and all his men scattered.

5.verse: and that night the king and his troops made a hole in the inner wall and fled out toward the Arabah through a gate that lay between the double walls near the king’s garden. The Babylonian troops surrounding the city took out after him and captured him in the plains of Jericho, and all his men scattered.

6.verse: He was taken to Riblah, where he was tried and sentenced before the king of Babylon.

7.verse: He was forced to watch as his sons were killed before his eyes; then his eyes were put out, and he was bound with chains and taken away to Babylon.

8.verse: General Nebuzaradan, the captain of the royal bodyguard, arrived at Jerusalem from Babylon on July 22 of the nineteenth year of the reign of King Nebuchadnezzar.

9.verse: He burned down the Temple, the palace, and all the other houses of any worth.

10.verse: He then supervised the Babylonian army in tearing down the walls of Jerusalem.

11.verse: The remainder of the people in the city and the Jewish deserters who had declared their allegiance to the king of Babylon were all taken as exiles to Babylon.

12.verse: But the poorest of the people were left to farm the land.

13.verse: The Babylonians broke up the bronze pillars of the Temple and the bronze tank and its bases and carried all the bronze to Babylon.

14.verse: They also took all the pots, shovels, firepans, snuffers, spoons, and other bronze instruments used for the sacrifices. The gold and silver bowls, with all the rest of the gold and silver, were melted down to bullion.

15.verse: They also took all the pots, shovels, firepans, snuffers, spoons, and other bronze instruments used for the sacrifices. The gold and silver bowls, with all the rest of the gold and silver, were melted down to bullion.

16.verse: It was impossible to estimate the weight of the two pillars and the great tank and its bases—all made for the Temple by King Solomon—because they were so heavy.

17.verse: Each pillar was 27 feet high, with an intricate bronze network of pomegranates decorating the 4½-foot capitals at the tops of the pillars.

18.verse: The general took Seraiah, the chief priest, his assistant Zephaniah, and the three Temple guards to Babylon as captives.

19.verse: A commander of the army of Judah, the chief recruiting officer, five of the king’s counselors, and sixty farmers, all of whom were discovered hiding in the city,

20.verse: were taken by General Nebuzaradan to the king of Babylon at Riblah,

21.verse: where they were put to the sword and died. So Judah was exiled from its land.

22.verse: Then King Nebuchadnezzar appointed Gedaliah (the son of Ahikam and grandson of Shaphan) as governor over the people left in Judah.

23.verse: When the Israeli guerrilla forces learned that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah as governor, some of these underground leaders and their men joined him at Mizpah. These included Ishmael, the son of Nethaniah; Johanan, the son of Kareah; Seraiah, the son of Tanhumeth the Netophathite; and Jaazaniah, son of Maachathite, and their men.

24.verse: Gedaliah vowed that if they would give themselves up and submit to the Babylonians, they would be allowed to live in the land and would not be exiled.

25.verse: But seven months later, Ishmael, who was a member of the royal line, went to Mizpah with ten men and killed Gedaliah and his court—both the Jews and the Babylonians.

26.verse: Then all the men of Judah and the guerrilla leaders fled in panic to Egypt, for they were afraid of what the Babylonians would do to them.

27.verse: King Jehoiachin was released from prison on the twenty-seventh day of the last month of the thirty-seventh year of his captivity. This occurred during the first year of the reign of King Evil-merodach of Babylon.

28.verse: He treated Jehoiachin kindly and gave him preferential treatment over all the other kings who were being held as prisoners in Babylon.

29.verse: Jehoiachin was given civilian clothing to replace his prison garb, and for as long as he lived, he ate regularly at the king’s table.

30.verse: The king also gave him a daily cash allowance for the rest of his life.
